member.name: M:Galaxon.BigNumbers.BigDecimalTests.ConstantsTests.TestComputePi10000
member.remarks: This takes a few minutes (about 7 on my computer at the time of typing), so sit back, relax, sip your coffee, and enjoy the relentless march of time.

member.name: M:Galaxon.BigNumbers.BigDecimalTests.ExpLogTests.TestSqrtBig
member.summary: Used https://keisan.casio.com/calculator to get expected result.

member.name: M:Galaxon.BigNumbers.BigDecimalTests.ExpLogTests.TestSqrtSmall
member.summary: Used https://keisan.casio.com/calculator to get expected result.

member.name: M:Galaxon.BigNumbers.BigDecimalTests.ExpLogTests.TestSqrtBiggerThanBiggestDouble
member.summary: In this test, both the initial argument and the square root are larger than the largest possible double value. Used https://keisan.casio.com/calculator to get expected result.

member.name: M:Galaxon.BigNumbers.BigDecimalTests.ExpLogTests.TestSqrtSmallerThanSmallestDouble
member.summary: In this test, both the initial argument and the square root are smaller than the largest possible double value. Used https://keisan.casio.com/calculator to get expected result.

member.name: M:Galaxon.BigNumbers.BigDecimalTests.ExpLogTests.TestCubeRootOfNegativeValueUsingPow
member.summary: This shows how the cube root of a negative value cannot be achieved using Pow(), because a BigDecimal cannot represent 1/3 exactly. You have to use Cbrt() or RootN().

member.name: M:Galaxon.BigNumbers.BigDecimalTests.RoundTests.TestRoundingMethods
member.summary: Check BigDecimal.Round() matches decimal.Round() for all rounding methods.
